generif.text: The gene TLOC1/SEC62 revealed the highest frequency (50%) of copy number gains in the prostate cancer and was found to be up-regulated at the mRNA level.

after silencing of SEC62 the cell migration and the invasive potential of the cells was blocked or at least dramatically reduced while cell viability was hardly affected. SEC62 gene may indeed be considered a target gene in the therapy of various tumors
Our data indicate a crucial function of Sec62 in the response to thapsigargin-induced endoplasmic reticulum stress.
The results indicate that SEC62 represents a potential candidate oncogene in the amplified 3q region in cases of non-small cell lung cancer.
Silencing the SEC62 gene inhibits post-translational transport of small presecretory proteins into endoplasmic reticulum.

the Sec62-dependent translocation pathway serves as a fail-safe mechanism to ensure efficient secretion of small proteins and provides cells with an opportunity to regulate secretion of small proteins independent of the signal recognition particle pathway
These results revealed that cyclin B1 and Sec62 may be candidate biomarkers and potential therapeutic targets for HBV-related HCC recurrence after surgery.
Phosphorylation of Sec63 by CK2 enhanced its binding to Sec62
these studies identify TLOC1 and SKIL as driver genes at 3q26 and more broadly suggest that cooperating genes may be coamplified in other regions with somatic copy number gain.
Sec62 overproduction significantly correlates with reduced non-small lung cancer patient survival.
High Sec62 expression is associated with dysplastic cervical lesions.
identify Sec62 as a critical molecular component in maintenance and recovery of endoplasmic reticulum homeostasis

Results show higher SEC62 in the lymph node metastases from head and neck squamous cell carcinomas and cervical cancer of unknown primary patients compared with the primary tumor. Tumors from N1 to N3 stage exhibit increasing SEC62 expression in the lymphatic metastases. Its knockdown resulted in tumor cell line migration inhibition while, its overexpression stimulated cell migration.

In tissue samples from 53 breast cancer patients,found increased SEC62 protein levels in tumor tissue compared to tumor-free tissue from the same patients. Tumors with high SEC62 expression or containing isolated cells with high SEC62 staining had more frequently distant metastases. ). Overall survival was significantly worse in BC patients with high SEC62 expression and in cases with isolated-intense SEC62 staining.
miR-4429 prevented gastric cancer progression through targeting METTL3 to inhibit m(6)A-caused stabilization of SEC62
Identification of signal peptide features for substrate specificity in human Sec62/Sec63-dependent ER protein import.
Sec62 promotes stemness and chemoresistance of human colorectal cancer through activating Wnt/beta-catenin pathway.
Sec62 promotes gastric cancer metastasis through mediating UPR-induced autophagy activation.
Splicing factor SNRPA associated with microvascular invasion promotes hepatocellular carcinoma metastasis through activating NOTCH1/Snail pathway and is mediated by circSEC62/miR-625-5p axis.
The 3q Oncogene SEC62 Predicts Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy and Regulates Tumor Cell Migration in Triple Negative Breast Cancer.

BP.term: post-translational protein targeting to endoplasmic reticulum membrane
post-translational protein targeting to membrane, translocation
post-translational protein targeting to membrane, translocation

name: SEC62 homolog, preprotein translocation factor
other_names: membrane protein SEC62, S.cerevisiae, homolog of

kegg.name: Protein processing in endoplasmic reticulum - Homo sapiens (human)

summary: The Sec61 complex is the central component of the protein translocation apparatus of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane. The protein encoded by this gene and SEC63 protein are found to be associated with ribosome-free SEC61 complex. It is speculated that Sec61-Sec62-Sec63 may perform post-translational protein translocation into the ER. The Sec61-Sec62-Sec63 complex might also perform the backward transport of ER proteins that are subject to the ubiquitin-proteasome-dependent degradation pathway. The encoded protein is an integral membrane protein located in the rough ER. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
